title: CNTIC provides loan — via accounts receivables financing facility arrangement — for 90MW Myingyan Gas-Fired Power Station Project
description: In September 2020, Deutsche Bank announced that it had signed a $43 million accounts receivables financing facility agreement with China National Technical Import & Export Corporation (CNTIC) for the 90MW Myingyan Gas-Fired Power Station Project. CNTIC, in turn, used the proceeds from the facility to on-lend to Electric Power Generation Enterprise (EPGE) of Myanmar (likely through a deferred payment agreement) for the 90MW Myingyan Gas-Fired Power Station Project. The borrowing terms of the loan to EPGE are unknown. However, it is known that the loan is backed by a Sinosure credit insurance policy.   The purpose of the project is to construct a 90MW gas-fired power station project in Myingyan township within the Mandalay region. The plant is being developed and operated by Hong Kong-based VPower under a five-year power purchase agreement with Electric Power Generation Enterprise (EPGE). CNTIC is the EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. The power plant was put into operation on February 1, 2019.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 缅甸敏建 90MW燃气电站项目 or 中技公司缅甸发电站项目. 2. More likely than not, Deutsche Bank signed an accounts receivable transfer agreement with CNTIC to provide financing for the construction period of the project. In this type of arrangement, the exporter (seller) procures insurance from an insurer and transfers its accounts receivable under the insurance policy to a bank. The bank then grants financing to the exporter (seller) and becomes the insured under the transferred insurance policy. When an insured loss occurs, the insurer pays indemnity to the financing bank pursuant to the insurance policy and the Accounts Receivable Transfer Agreement. 3. In a typical receivables financing agreement (or deferred payment agreement), the company that the project owner in the host country has selected as its engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contractor is also a lender to the project owner. The company assigns receivables under its EPC contract with the project owner to one of or more banks. Upon assignment of receivables, the bank or banks will release funds to the company so it can discharge its obligations under the receivables financing agreement as a lender. Receivables financing is also known as accounts receivable financing (finance) or A/R financing (finance) or 应收账款融资 (in Chinese). These other terms are used because the accounts receivable of a company (i.e., unpaid invoices) are being used as collateral to unlock working capital—typically in the form of a bank loan (‘receivables loan’). Sellers often face cash flow problems when their buyers do not make full payment at the due date of the invoice. A receivables financing arrangement addresses this problem by allowing them to sell their outstanding invoices to a bank at a discounted rate. This approach allows the seller to receive the remaining invoice amount before the due date of the invoice. The bank either gets its money back at invoice maturity through the seller (acting as a collecting agent) or directly from the debtor. 4. CNTIC, a large-scale state-owned enterprise and a wholly-owned subsidiary of China General Technology (Group) Holding Ltd. (‘Genertec’). 5. EPGE is Myanmar’s state-owned electricity company.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
CNTIC provides loan — via accounts receivables financing facility arrangement — for 90MW Myingyan Gas-Fired Power Station Project

# Description
In September 2020, Deutsche Bank announced that it had signed a $43 million accounts receivables financing facility agreement with China National Technical Import & Export Corporation (CNTIC) for the 90MW Myingyan Gas-Fired Power Station Project. CNTIC, in turn, used the proceeds from the facility to on-lend to Electric Power Generation Enterprise (EPGE) of Myanmar (likely through a deferred payment agreement) for the 90MW Myingyan Gas-Fired Power Station Project. The borrowing terms of the loan to EPGE are unknown. However, it is known that the loan is backed by a Sinosure credit insurance policy.   The purpose of the project is to construct a 90MW gas-fired power station project in Myingyan township within the Mandalay region. The plant is being developed and operated by Hong Kong-based VPower under a five-year power purchase agreement with Electric Power Generation Enterprise (EPGE). CNTIC is the EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. The power plant was put into operation on February 1, 2019.
justification: Primary purpose is gas-fired power generation, which has a complex relationship with energy transition goals
evidence: 90MW gas-fired power station, natural gas as primary fuel source

title: China donates COVID-19 equipment to Namibia in April 2020
description: On April 23, 2020 China donated medical equipment and protective gear to Namibia. The donation contains 20,000 N95 Medical Masks, 10,000 General Medical Masks, 2,000 Disposable Medical Protective Gowns, 2,000 Medical Goggles, 500 Portable Infrared Thermometers, and 10,000 Medical Shoe Covers.   The donation arrived at the Hosea Kutako International Airport in Windhoek. It was handed over along with another donation from the Jack Ma Foundation.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.
combined_text:

# Title

The donation contains 20,000 N95 Medical Masks, 10,000 General Medical Masks, 2,000 Disposable Medical Protective Gowns, 2,000 Medical Goggles, 500 Portable Infrared Thermometers, and 10,000 Medical Shoe Covers.   The donation arrived at the Hosea Kutako International Airport in Windhoek. It was handed over along with another donation from the Jack Ma Foundation.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare support with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of medical equipment and protective gear for COVID-19 response

title: Nanjing donates 30,000 face masks to the city of Windhoek in June 2020
description: On June 1, 2020, the Chinese city of Nanjing donated 30,000 face masks to the city of Windhoek in Namibia. The ambassador of the People’s Republic of China in Namibia, Zhang Yiming, and other senior Chinese embassy personnel officiated at the handover ceremony in Windhoek. This donation was expected to deepen the friendship between the two cities after they became sister cities in 2015.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.

title: Shanghai donates 20,000 masks to Windhoek, Namibia in May 2020
description: On May 22, 2020, the city of Shanghai donated 20,000 masks to its sister city of Windhoek, Namibia. The donation includes 3000 surgical and 17000 KN95 masks. The donation was handed over by the Chinese Embassy in Namibia.

title: Jiangsu donates 50,000 masks to Khomas region, Namibia in June 2020
description: On June 16, 2020, Chinese ambassador to Namibia Zhang Yiming handed over 50 000 masks to Khomas region that had been donated by Jiangsu province. The government in the Khomas region will distribute these masks among all districts.

title: China donates NAD 4.3 million in COVID-19 equipment to Namibia in July 2020
description: On July 15, 2020, China donated PPE consignments worth N$4.3 million (260,000 U.S. dollars). The donation included 150 000 surgical masks, 5 000 medical disposable protective clothing, 15 000 protective face masks for medical use, 7 000 medical protective goggles, 7 000 pairs of disposable sterilized rubber surgical gloves, and 3 000 pairs of medical isolation shoe covers. Namibian Health Minister Kalumbi Shangula and Chinese Ambassador to Namibia Zhang Yiming attended the handover ceremony in Windhoek, Namibia.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China donates NAD 4.3 million in COVID-19 equipment to Namibia in July 2020

# Description
On July 15, 2020, China donated PPE consignments worth N$4.3 million (260,000 U.S. dollars). The donation included 150 000 surgical masks, 5 000 medical disposable protective clothing, 15 000 protective face masks for medical use, 7 000 medical protective goggles, 7 000 pairs of disposable sterilized rubber surgical gloves, and 3 000 pairs of medical isolation shoe covers. Namibian Health Minister Kalumbi Shangula and Chinese Ambassador to Namibia Zhang Yiming attended the handover ceremony in Windhoek, Namibia.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare equipment donation without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Donation of PPE and medical equipment for COVID-19 response

title: Chinese Ambassador donates 1,000 COVID-19 testing kits to Namibia in March 2020
description: On March 18, 2020, Chinese Ambassador H.E Zhang Yiming donated 1,000 reagent testing kits to the Namibian government to be used in the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic. The handover ceremony was held in the capital of Windhoek.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.

title: Chinese first lady donated COVID-19 equipment to the Namibian first lady's One Economy Foundation in July 2020 (linked to Project ID #93216)
description: On July 10, 2020, the Chinese first lady donated 18000 Medical Masks and 120 infrared thermometers to the first lady of Namibia, Monica Geingos' One Economy Foundation. The donation was made specifically to help women and children.   The Chinese ambassador to Namibia facilitated the handover of the supplies, which were to be distributed to survivors of gender based violence and to youth organizations. The donation was made alongside a donation of 30 sewing machines by the Chinese Embassy (Project ID #93216).
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.

title: China sends the 13th medical team to Namibia
description: On January 16, 2020, the arrival ceremony for the 13th Chinese medical team in Namibia was held at Katutura Hospital in Windhoek. The team consisted of two doctors and two nurses, all of whom practiced traditional Chinese medicine. They returned to China on October 26, 2021, 3 months delayed from the original departure time in July, 2021 due to COVID-19.   During their 18-month stay in Namibia, the team treated more than 7,000 Namibian people, and introduced traditional Chinese medicine practices.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China sends the 13th medical team to Namibia

# Description
On January 16, 2020, the arrival ceremony for the 13th Chinese medical team in Namibia was held at Katutura Hospital in Windhoek. The team consisted of two doctors and two nurses, all of whom practiced traditional Chinese medicine. They returned to China on October 26, 2021, 3 months delayed from the original departure time in July, 2021 due to COVID-19.   During their 18-month stay in Namibia, the team treated more than 7,000 Namibian people, and introduced traditional Chinese medicine practices.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare services without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical team providing healthcare services, traditional Chinese medicine practices
